_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE

POLICIES

The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work

environment. A Safety and Risk Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe

practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving

hazardous chemicals. This site makes use of the Clayton County Emergency

Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia

emergencies. The site has specific and written evacuation and reporting

procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the

environment in the event of an ammonia release.



1.2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 1361 Southern Road,

Morrow, Georgia.

The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for

consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported

and distributed from this site. The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.

One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce. Fresh

Express has developed a Risk Management Program in compliance with the

Environmental Protection Agency's final Rule 40 CFR Part 68. The regulated

substance is anhydrous ammonia with a total inventory charge over the threshold

quantity of 10,000 lbs. Since the facility is also subject to the Occupational

Safety and Health Administration's PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119, Program 3

is required.



1.3 THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND

THE CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished

through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system

design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications,

and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.

* Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial

construction and mo

dification

* Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) at least once every

five years using accurate Process Safety Information

* Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA

* Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance

personnel

* Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system

component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous

energy lockout and hot work permit programs

* Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review

protocols

* Use of qualified contractors for work on the system

The detailed Ammonia System Release Prevention Program is contained in a

supporting document (revised and updated March, 2017) which is maintained at the

site Safety Office.



1.4 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Between June 2015 (the previous revalidation of the site program) and the

present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or

property damage, or off-site environmental damage.

There is no accident history in the past five years.



1.5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Fresh Express is included in the written community emergency response plan.

The facility has its own emergency action plan. The emergency action plan

includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a

chemical release. The emergency action plan also includes information on

emergency health care.

Fresh Express does not respond to emergencies. Fresh Express coordinates its

Emergency Action Plan with the Clayton County Fire Department.



1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Fresh Express has performed a hazard analysis, compliance audits, and a

mechanical integrity audits per their Process Safety Management and Risk

Management programs. Areas for improvement were identified and corrective

actions recommended. All recommendations are promptly addressed.
